General humour

Humour is widely interpreted

Not everything here is meant to be laugh out loud - some is just amusing stories.

Academic papers

A fantastic paper by Anne Cutler titled The perception of rhythm in language - if you don’t get it and think it a rather dry academic paper then there is a footnote at the bottom of the page for you

Cartoons

Bird on a wire

Stories

This story where Lori Baker’s husband (and Lori herself) are alerted by accident to fact that her Tetris playing ability is world champion level - and according to this leaderboard the record she set is still in the top 5 in the world. (Ending of story does rather lean into sexist division of labour.)

“This isn’t the 1800s. You can’t pay me with a horse” - I think Donald J. Trump has a reputation for trying to reduce the amount he pays suppliers - not an amusing tendency in general but this time it went somewhere funny.

How slow is the world’s fastest aircraft? A pilot recounts the slowest he went in a Lockheed SR-71 (even in 2022 apparently the fastest airbreathing manned aircraft).

This is the reporter Damon Green’s story on how this interview happened. It is a less serious version of the Jeremy Paxman/William Hague interview - where Paxman goes through some version of “you asked him?” nine times to try and get an answer re: Lord Ashcroft’s tax status. Beyond the ironic humour and surreal elements of Green’s story the serious point is the issues with politicians not giving anything away that is not a prepared soundbite.

Movies

Really a New York Times (NYT) thing - where they will go to really regressive places - despite having some good reporters.

NYT: Yes Sauron Can Be Quite Aggressive But Consider Hobbits Who Go Around Throwing People's Jewelry Into Lava Pits

— Daniel José Older (@djolder) July 4, 2022

Music

A masterpiece by Mozart

The multipart take on a classic:

Your biceps are beyond compare
with bulging muscles everywhere
chiseled quads, and pecs like Wolverine
Your jawline hard as winter rain
your brow is proud, a jutting plane
I cannot compete with you Brolene pic.twitter.com/W4xc3D64Os

— Hadassah Grace (@GraceHadassah) August 29, 2019

Take all my isolated whey
My protein bars, pants tearaway
but leave my only love to me Brolene

— Hadassah Grace (@GraceHadassah) August 29, 2019

Another song:

some
body once told me
this bird was gonna scold me
while perching on my Pallas bust's head
I was lookin kinda glum
and mourning what's become
of my lost love lenore
who is dead

— Are You There, God? It's Me, Margit (@jephjacques) October 31, 2021

Last 3 paragraphs of this Andrew Lloyd-Webber interview in Variety on how he got a dog - and the way he got permission for the dog to fly with him.

PR

Masterclass in PR by a young woman fielding paparazzi questions.

Historical Hatemail - Scottish comedian Eleanor Morton reading in the character of a variety of European historical figures their imagined hatemail.

Not all things that look like bot social media accounts are bots:

someone liked a ton of my tweets at once and their account has 0 followers and was JUST made, and I thought, “this must be a bot.” then I looked closer. it’s my dad.

— Karen Chee (@karencheee) October 15, 2020

In his book Why don’t students like school? Daniel T. Willingham points out effective communication involves leaving things out - comedian Kim Quindlen puts it all in here:

Literally any podcast host asking their guest a question pic.twitter.com/So4WUqFSXj

— Kim Quindlen (@kimquindlen) November 17, 2021

The subject lines fit:

I didn't even know we were dating pic.twitter.com/qDapMOmpHp

— maura quint (@behindyourback) February 1, 2022

(Nancy Pelosi is a US Congresswoman who is the first female Speaker of the House and is seen here fundraising).

Social media will let you know there is a genre of people, particularly men, who will write to a woman they have not met asking them to change something fairly irrelevant to fit in with the writer’s preconceptions.

Fortunately Molly White has a perfect reply to just such a case:

the trick is to write "respectfully yours" at the end so he can't get mad pic.twitter.com/kzXvxqQDCW

— Molly White (@molly0xFFF) May 26, 2022

Unintended consequences

Stories of Americans not paying attention to the public health information that suggests they have coronavirus are stories with the capacity to amuse but aren’t really funny - it is an attitude getting people sick or dead at the population level. But the following at least is in Shanghai where, if not universally competently, the government actually has an anti-COVID plan that targets coronavirus infections rather than “politically unacceptable levels of death from COVID”. So here this is:

Loose translation: a Japanese guy got Covid-19 in Shanghai a little while ago so the city published a list of places he went for contact tracing…which people are now using as a restaurant guide for authentic Japanese food in the city https://t.co/1MVXr5wNKd

— Gavin Cross (@thanksgaving) December 21, 2021

Foreseeable unintended consequences

Taiwan was engulfed in "salmon chaos" (鮭魚之亂) this week as more than 300 people legally changed their names to "salmon" (鮭魚) to take advantage of a promotion at a Taiwanese sushi chain.

A thread.

1/https://t.co/gT42LaNCjK

— Nick Kapur (@nick_kapur) March 20, 2021

In conclusion

If you got the idea I like slightly wordy, slightly absurd, sometimes satirical humour from all that then I’ve curated this OK.

Footnote

Re: Cutler paper: try reading the paper out loud yourself or if that is no better try a web search about the paper/ask a few native English speakers to try reading out loud to see if they do it differently than you do.
